questions.text: A 28 year old man presents with recurrent abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding. Imaging studies reveal the presence of multiple gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) in his stomach. His medical history includes a diagnosis of paragangliomas, and his mother has a history of lung tumors. What is the most likely genetic syndrome associated with this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Carney’s Triad

Explanation:

In this patient, the presence of multiple GISTs and a prior history of paragangliomas, along with a family history suggestive of pulmonary tumors, is consistent with the diagnosis of Carney’s

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

  • Clinical features:
    • GI Bleed (most common)
    • Abdominal Pain
    • Weight loss
    • Large abdominal mass- it arises from the submucosa - hence it is extraluminal- but expands and compresses the mucosa
    • Metastasis to liver 

Carney’s Triad:

It is a rare syndrome characterized by the presence of three specific tumors: gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), extra-adrenal paragangliomas, and pulmonary chondromas.

 

Tumor Type

Characteristics

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs)
  • Often found in the stomach and multifocal.
  • Distinct from sporadic GISTs (no c-KIT or PDGFRA mutations).
  • May exhibit loss of genetic material on chromosome 1. Associated with SDH deficiency.

Paragangliomas
  • Arise from paraganglia (neuroendocrine cell clusters).
  • Typically extra-adrenal. Can occur in various locations.

Pulmonary Chondromas
  • Benign tumors of cartilage.
  • Found in the lungs.

 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) (Option A) is characterized by skin changes, such as café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and an increased risk of various tumors, including malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While NF1 can be associated with GISTs.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) (Option C) is characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of polyps in the colon and rectum, leading to a high risk of colorectal cancer. It is not associated with GISTs or paragangliomas.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (Option D) is characterized by intestinal polyps and mucocutaneous pigmentation, along with an increased risk of various cancers, including gastrointestinal cancers. However, it is not associated with GISTs or paragangliomas.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman presents with fatigue, loss of appetite, and a palpable mass in the upper abdomen. Endoscopic examination and biopsy confirmed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the stomach. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chemotherapy with R-CHOP

 

Explanation:

The R-CHOP regimen, which includes Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, and Prednisone, is the standard treatment for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the stomach. This combination therapy is designed to target the aggressive nature of DLBCL and is effective in managing the disease.

 

Note:

  • Gastric lymphoma, including MALToma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), involves malignancies originating in the stomach.
  • Gastric MALT lymphoma is often associated with Helicobacter pylori infection and can be treated initially with H. pylori eradication therapy.
  • In contrast, DLBCL usually requires a combination of chemotherapy (such as the R-CHOP regimen) and may involve surgery or radiation therapy for specific complications or cases.

H. pylori eradication therapy (Option A) is effective for treating gastric MALToma due to its association with the bacterium, it is not adequate for managing diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) of the stomach.


Radiation therapy alone (Option B) can be part of the treatment plan, particularly in cases where there are localized complications or in combination with other therapies, it is not usually effective as a standalone treatment for this aggressive lymphoma.

 

Immunotherapy with checkpoint inhibitors (Option D) is not considered the first-line treatment. Although it represents a promising area of research, the standard initial treatment remains chemotherapy with R-CHOP.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their corresponding X-ray findings:


	
		
			
			i) Teapot stomach
			
			
			a) 

			
			
		
		
			
			ii) Hourglass stomach
			
			
			b) 

			
			
		
		
			
			iii) Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
			
			
			c) 

			
			
		
		
			
			iv) Leather bottle stomach
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-c

 

Explanation:

i) Teapot stomach

d) 
  • The Teapot Stomach, also known as "Hand-bag stomach," is a deformity caused by scarring and shortening of the lesser curvature of the stomach.
  • This condition is usually a complication of gastric ulcers.
  • The deformity leads to symptoms similar to those of pyloric stenosis, such as vomiting and gastric outlet obstruction.

ii) Hourglass stomach

a) 
  • Hourglass Stomach is a deformity of the stomach caused by cicatrial contracture of lesser curvature, often associated with gastric ulcers.
  • This fibrosis divides the stomach into two compartments, creating an hourglass shape.
  • Symptoms include persistent pain, vomiting, loss of appetite, and weight loss.
  • On a barium meal X-ray, this condition is identified by the double-pouched appearance, indicating two separate sections within the stomach.

iii) Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

b) 
  • CHPS is a condition in infants where the musculature of the pyloric antrum, particularly the circular muscle fibres, thickens.
  • This thickening leads to the primary failure of the pylorus to relax, resulting in pyloric obstruction.
  • Single bubble sign refers to the visible gas bubble in the stomach

iv) Leather bottle stomach

c) 
  • Leather Bottle Stomach, also known as linitis plastica, is a type of aggressive, diffuse gastric cancer (Type IV gastric carcinoma).
  • This condition involves enormous fibrous tissue proliferation in the submucosa of the stomach, causing diffuse thickening of the stomach walls.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with severe epigastric pain and inability to vomit despite repeated attempts. On examination, he has significant abdominal distention, and attempts to pass a nasogastric tube were unsuccessful. Which of the following best describes the condition represented by this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute gastric volvulus

Explanations:
The symptoms of unproductive retching, epigastric pain & distention, and inability to pass a nasogastric tube align with Borchardt's triad, indicating acute gastric volvulus.

Gastric Volvulus:

  • Definition: Rotation/Torsion of the stomach around the axis between the cardia and pylorus.
  • Types:
    • Horizontal (organoaxial)- rotation occurs in the horizontal direction (most common)
    • Vertical (mesentroaxial)- rotation occurs along the vertical direction
  • Associated Condition: Linked with para-esophageal herniation due to a diaphragmatic defect, causing the transverse colon and stomach shift upward.
  • Presentation:
    • Chronic: Difficulty eating.
    • Acute: Ischemia and risk of gastric infarction.
    • Diagnosis: Endoscopy may be challenging; contrast radiography is preferred.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical intervention, often laparoscopic.
    • Reposition hernial sac if present; close diaphragm defect with mesh.
    • Anterior gastropexy to prevent future rotation.

 

Gastric Cancer (Option A) can also cause abdominal pain and distention, but it is less likely to present with the specific symptoms of unproductive retching and inability to pass a nasogastric tube characteristic of gastric volvulus.

Peptic ulcer disease (Option C) can also cause abdominal pain and vomiting, they do not typically present with the hallmark symptoms of Borchardt's triad, particularly the inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) can also cause abdominal distention and vomiting, but the specific combination of symptoms described, particularly the unproductive retching and failure of the nasogastric tube, is more indicative of gastric volvulus.

Explanations:
Trichobezoars are hairballs that commonly occur in young females with psychiatric issues who swallow hair.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with vomiting, dehydration, and poor feeding. An abdominal X-ray shows a "double bubble" sign. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis from Duodenal Atresia?

choices.text: CHPS typically presents with bilious vomiting, while Duodenal Atresia presents with non-bilious vomiting.
In CHPS, infants are often hungry after vomiting, whereas in Duodenal Atresia, infants have no desire to feed.
Both conditions present with projectile vomiting, but CHPS is diagnosed by X-ray showing the "double bubble" sign.
Duodenal Atresia is commonly treated with Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy, whereas CHPS requires surgical correction of the duodenum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) In CHPS, infants are often hungry after vomiting, whereas in Duodenal Atresia, infants have no desire to feed.

Explanations:

Infants with CHPS generally show a desire to feed after vomiting, while those with Duodenal Atresia often do not due to the obstruction.

CHPS vs. Duodenal Atresia

Aspect

Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS)

Duodenal Atresia

Aetiology

Thickening of pyloric muscle

Congenital obstruction of the duodenum

Age of Presentation

3 to 6 weeks

Typically presents shortly after birth

Vomiting Characteristics

Forceful, non-bilious, projectile vomiting

Bilious vomiting due to distal obstruction

Feeding Behaviour

Infants are hungry and seek re-feeding

Often no desire to feed due to persistent vomiting

Physical Exam & X-ray Findings
  • Palpable “olive-like” mass in the right upper quadrant.
  • “Single bubble” sign on X-ray.

"Double bubble" sign on X-ray; no palpable mass.

 

Diagnosis 

Clinical history, physical exam, and ultrasound

X-ray or ultrasound showing a "double bubble" sign

Treatment

Surgical: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy; non-surgical not advised

Surgical: Duodenoduodenostomy or duodenojejunostomy required

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is diagnosed with Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis after presenting with projectile vomiting and signs of dehydration. The surgical team plans to perform Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy. Which of the following statements about this condition and its management is true?

choices.text: The incision during Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy should only involve the mucosal layer to avoid complications.
Infants with CHPS typically do not exhibit hunger after vomiting.
Postoperative intravenous fluids are administered until the infant can resume feeding, which usually occurs within 24 hours.
Persistent vomiting after surgery is primarily due to incomplete myotomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Postoperative intravenous fluids are administered until the infant can resume feeding, which usually occurs within 24 hours.

Explanation:
After surgery, intravenous fluids are given until the infant can begin feeding, typically within 24 hours.

Treatment of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS)

1. Fluid Resuscitation: To correct the hypokalemia, hypochloremia & metabolic alkalosis

  • 0.9% saline
  • 0.15%KCl
  • 5% glucose

2. Surgical Treatment:

  • Procedure: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy
    • Can be performed laparoscopically or via incision in the supraumbilical or right upper quadrant.
    • Involves incision in the serosa of the pylorus while preserving the submucosa from the duodenum to the gastric antrum.
    • The incision must extend onto the stomach to prevent an early recurrence.

3. Postoperative Care:

  • Intravenous fluids are administered until the infant can resume feeding, typically within 24 hours.
  • Some vomiting may occur immediately after surgery but usually resolves quickly.
  • Persistent vomiting is more likely due to gastro-esophageal reflux rather than incomplete myotomy.

The incision during Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy should only involve the mucosal layer to avoid complications (Option A), The incision must involve the serosa of the pylorus while preserving the submucosa to prevent complications.

Infants with CHPS typically do not exhibit hunger after vomiting (Option B), Infants with CHPS often show hunger after vomiting, distinguishing it from vomiting caused by infections.

Persistent vomiting after surgery is primarily due to incomplete myotomy (Option D), Persistent vomiting is more likely due to gastroesophageal reflux rather than incomplete myotomy.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with persistent projectile non-bilious vomiting, dehydration, and weight loss. The physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound shows a thickened pylorus. Which of the following electrolyte imbalances is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypokalemia

Explanations:

The given condition is congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Persistent vomiting causes a loss of gastric acid (HCl), leading to metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia, which is a common electrolyte disturbance in infants with pyloric stenosis.

Diagnosis of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS)

1. Clinical Presentation:

  • Typical onset: 3 to 6 weeks of age
  • Symptoms:
    • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting
    • Visible gastric peristalsis
    • Palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen (hypertrophied pylorus), best felt from the left side
    • Dyselectrolytemias-
      • Hypochloremia
      • Hypokalemia due to persistent vomiting
      • Metabolic acidosis(due to loss of H+).

2. Imaging Techniques:

  • Ultrasound (Gold Standard):
    • Characteristic "doughnut sign" indicating thickened pyloric muscle
    • Diagnostic criteria:
      • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
      • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
      • "Cervix sign" on long-axis view
      • "Target sign" on short-axis view
  • Barium Meal (Less Common):
    • Can assist in diagnosis but is less accurate than ultrasound
    • Signs suggestive of CHPS:
      • "String sign": Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
      • "Railroad track sign": Two thin lines of contrast indicating mild narrowing
      • "Double track sign": Similar to railroad track sign, indicating thickened muscle

Hyperkalemia (Option A) refers to elevated potassium levels, which are not typically associated with pyloric stenosis. Persistent vomiting usually leads to low potassium levels.

Hypernatremia (Option B), While dehydration can lead to elevated sodium levels, hypernatremia is not a characteristic finding specifically associated with pyloric stenosis.

Hypocalcemia (Option D) refers to low calcium levels, which is not typically associated with pyloric stenosis or vomiting and is not the expected electrolyte disturbance in this condition.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with complaints of persistent abdominal pain and weight loss. After evaluation, he is diagnosed with resectable gastric cancer. Based on the information provided, which of the following treatment options would likely offer the best median overall survival for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen

Explanation:
The FLOT regimen has been demonstrated to provide a significant survival advantage, with a median overall survival of 50 months as per the FLOT4 trial. This makes it the most effective neoadjuvant chemotherapy option for patients diagnosed with resectable gastric cancer, thus making this the correct answer.

Treatment of Stomach Cancer

  • Surgical Treatment:

    • Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for gastric cancer.
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy:
      • Most surgical candidates receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve survival.
      • The FLOT4 trial found that the FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen offers a significant survival advantage over the ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (median overall survival: 50 months vs 35 months).

Types of Gastric Resection

  • Total Gastrectomy:
    • Involves the removal of the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.
    • Includes D2 lymphadenectomy.
    • Preferred for resectable gastric cancer.
  • Subtotal Gastrectomy:
    • May be performed if the tumour is located in the distal stomach.
    • Involves Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative Surgery:
    • Considered for symptom alleviation in inoperable or metastatic gastric cancer.

Non-Surgical Treatment

  • Palliative Chemotherapy or Radiotherapy: Offered to patients with advanced gastric cancer.

ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (Option A) has been a standard chemotherapy protocol for gastric cancer; however, recent clinical trials, such as the FLOT4 trial, have shown that it offers a lower median overall survival (50 months vs 35 months) compared to the FLOT regimen.

Palliative chemotherapy (Option C) is typically offered to patients with advanced or metastatic gastric cancer, where the intent is not curative but to alleviate symptoms.

Total gastrectomy without prior chemotherapy (Option D), While total gastrectomy may be an appropriate surgical option for resectable gastric cancer, proceeding without prior neoadjuvant chemotherapy would not give the same results. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is recommended to enhance surgical outcomes and overall survival.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with vague epigastric discomfort and constant, non-radiating pain that is not related to food intake. He has a history of iron deficiency anaemia. Considering the regional differences in the prevalence of stomach cancer sites, what is the most likely location of his cancer if he resides in the West?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Proximal stomach
 

Explanation:

In Western countries, stomach cancer is most commonly found in the proximal stomach, near the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Distal stomach (Option A): This is more commonly the site for stomach cancer in Asian countries.

 

Antrum of the stomach (Option C): While it can be affected in various gastric conditions, it is not the most common site for stomach cancer in the West.

 

Body of the stomach (Option D): This area is often affected by pernicious anaemia, which involves the parietal cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and a palpable epigastric mass. CT shows a well-defined stomach mass. Biopsy confirms a gastrointestinal stromal tumor, with CD117 and DOG1 positivity. Which statement is most accurate about this patient?

choices.text: CD117 positivity confirms the diagnosis of GIST, and DOG1 is not relevant
The primary treatment for GISTs is chemotherapy
Surgery is the mainstay of treatment for localized GISTs
GISTs most commonly occur in the small intestine and are rarely found in the stomach

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Surgery is the mainstay of treatment for localized GISTs.

Explanation:
Surgical resection is the primary treatment for localized GISTs, aiming to remove the tumour completely.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)

  • Common Locations:
    • Stomach: 60-70% of cases.
    • Small Intestine: 20-30%.
    • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).

 

  • Origin: The Interstitial cells of Cajal (Gastric pacemaker cells)

  • Immunohistochemistry Markers for GISTs

Category

Marker

Expression in GISTs

Significance
 

Old Markers

CD117 (c-KIT)

Expressed in approximately 97% of GISTs

Crucial for diagnosis

CD34

Expressed in 70% GISTs

Associated with hematopoietic progenitor cells

SMA

Some GISTs show positivity

Less common compared to CD117 and CD34



 

New Markers

PDGFRA

Mutations found in approximately 5-10% of GISTs

Additional diagnostic marker

DOG1

Expressed in many GISTs, including those negative for CD117

Alternative diagnostic tool

 

CD117 positivity confirms the diagnosis of GIST, and DOG1 is not relevant (Option A), While CD117 positivity is crucial for diagnosing GIST, DOG1 is also a relevant and useful marker, especially for CD117-negative cases.

The primary treatment for GISTs is chemotherapy (Option B), The primary treatment for localized GISTs is surgical resection. Chemotherapy, particularly with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, is used in metastatic or unresectable cases and as adjuvant therapy.

GISTs most commonly occur in the small intestine and are rarely found in the stomach (Option D), GISTs are most commonly found in the stomach (60-70%) and then in the small intestine (20-30%).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with epigastric pain, weight loss, and early satiety for three months. On examination, mild epigastric tenderness is seen. Upper GI endoscopy reveals an ulcerated mass in the stomach antrum, confirmed as adenocarcinoma. Staging shows no distant metastases but involves perigastric lymph nodes. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by total gastrectomy
Subtotal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection
Subtotal gastrectomy with D2 lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Subtotal gastrectomy with D2 lymph node dissection

Explanation:
Subtotal gastrectomy is suitable for tumors in the antrum, and a D2 lymph node dissection involves removing the perigastric lymph nodes as well as nodes along the major arterial trunks. This extensive dissection is recommended in cases with lymph node involvement to ensure a more thorough removal of potentially cancerous nodes and to improve survival rates.

 

 

Primary Treatment of stomach cancer- Surgical Resection

  • Types of Surgical Resection:

    • Total Gastrectomy: Removes the entire stomach; used for proximal or middle stomach tumors.

    • Subtotal Gastrectomy: Removes a portion of the stomach; used for distal stomach tumors.

    • Lymph Node Dissection: D1 (perigastric nodes) or D2 (major arterial trunks) based on tumor location and stage.

    • Reconstruction: Roux-en-Y method connects the esophagus to the remaining stomach or small intestine.

  • Distal Pancreatectomy and Splenectomy: Part of radical gastrectomy to remove potentially cancerous lymph nodes.

Additional Treatments:

  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Platinum-based triplet regimen administered before surgery to improve survival rates. (ECF- Epirubicin, Cisplatin, 5-Flurouracil)

  • Palliative Treatment: For incurable diseases, options include chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and palliative surgery to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.

 

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by total gastrectomy (Option A) is often used for advanced gastric cancer to shrink the tumor before surgery, making it easier to remove and improving survival rates.

Subtotal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection (Option B) is appropriate for tumors in the distal stomach (such as the antrum). However, a D1 lymph node dissection involves only the removal of the perigastric lymph nodes and is considered less extensive than a D2 dissection.

Palliative chemotherapy (Option D) is used to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life in cases of incurable or metastatic gastric cancer. Since the patient has no distant metastases and the disease is potentially curable with surgery, palliative chemotherapy is not indicated in this situation.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with severe weight loss and loss of appetite. Endoscopic examination reveals a thickened, rigid stomach with a "mother of pearl" appearance. Biopsy shows poorly differentiated cells with signet ring cells. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Total gastrectomy with oesophagojejunal anastomosis

 

Explanation:

  • The symptoms and imaging point to Linitis Plastica which is a diffuse type of stomach cancer with enormous fibrous tissue proliferation in the submucosa.
  • Linitis plastica is a rare and aggressive form of gastric cancer.
  • The submucosa becomes thick, giving the stomach a ‘mother-of-pearl’ appearance. Plastica is leather-like.
  • Signet ring cells are often present.
  • The most appropriate treatment for linitis plastica is a total gastrectomy with oesophagojejunal anastomosis.
  • This procedure involves completely removing the stomach, followed by connecting the oesophagus directly to the jejunum. This extensive surgical approach is necessary due to the diffuse spread and aggressive nature of linitis plastica.

Partial gastrectomy (Option A) which involves removing only a portion of the stomach, is not adequate for treating linitis plastica.

Chemotherapy (Option B), While chemotherapy can be a part of the treatment plan, it is not sufficient by itself for managing linitis plastica.

Proton pump inhibitors and antibiotics (Option D) is typically used for managing peptic ulcer disease, especially when associated with H. pylori infection.
